#: by Robert Watkins's words the mind was *winged* :#
> Kent Beck wrote:
>> Robert,
>> 
>> This is an interesting idea. It would be very powerful. I'm having trouble
>> understanding what you would use it for beyond what you can do with
>> @Before/@After and @BeforeClass and @AfterClass, though. Do you have an
>> example?
> 
> Kent,
> 
> It's not so much that I think it couldn't be done with the existing 
> annotations, as that it would be more elegant if a decorator annotation was 
> directly available.
> 
> An example that I've got right at hand is a decorator I used to set up the 
> JNDI space with mock objects, so that the code-under-test had access to 
> expected resources. I used a decorator, rather than a base class, because I 
> needed this to be available across several different test hierarchies, some 
> of which already extended from different sub-class of TestCase. An 
> alternative would have been to use a duplicated setUp() method. But this 
> was ugly duplication... Another good example would be for using IoC 
> techniques on the test itself.
> 
> With the @Before/@After annotations, I could do something similar. But it 
> would still be duplication that would be annoying. With an annotation 
> decorator I'd be able to reduce that duplication to a single declaration of 
> intent.
> 
> More generally, however, I'd like a way to extend JUnit without fighting 
> it. There are some powerful techniques in JUnit 3.8 that I wouldn't want to 
> lose, for example - one such is the ability to programatically create test 
> cases (see http://twasink.net/blog/archives/2003/10/junit_and_datad.html 
> for more on this - or Chapter 4.8 of JB Rainsberger's "JUnit Recipes"). In 
> JUnit 4, there appears to be no way to do the same thing; I'd be forced to 
> have a single test, which read the data file iteratively - needless to say, 
> this wouldn't give me the same level of granularity in reports.
> 
> In fact, in order to get the same level of flexibility in JUnit 4 as is in 
> JUnit 3, you'd need at the very least to give an equivalent of the suite() 
> method - currently, there is no way to change the way that test instances 
> are obtained. Perhaps a test class could define a TestFactory annotation, 
> which would default to the TestInstropector?
> 
> (Actually, for the ultimate in flexibility, you'd need to provide a way to 
> change the runner strategy, too - but that's probably overkill)
> 
> Ultimately, what I would like to be able to do is have equivalents of 
> popular JUnit extensions, such as DBUnit, ServletUnit, and JUnitPerf, which 
> are configured using annotations rather than base classes. The annotations 
> currently in JUnit 4 wouldn't allow this.
> 
> (Cedric, if you're reading this... every one of these points applies to 
> TestNG as well)
> 

I am not sure which ones are not _already_ available ;-). I will pass again through it to check.
